title: Understanding confidential IPOs
content_simple: 8 October 2025 ‚Ä¢ Capital Markets Understanding confidential IPOs In today‚Äôs Finshots, we tell you why more and more Indian companies are taking the confidential pre-filing IPO route before hitting the bourses. But before we begin, if you‚Äôre someone who loves to keep tabs on what‚Äôs happening in the world of business and finance, then hit subscribe if you haven‚Äôt already. If you‚Äôre already a subscriber or you‚Äôre reading this on the app, you can just go ahead and read the story. The Story Let‚Äôs say it‚Äôs your 25th birthday next month, and you‚Äôre also expecting a fat Diwali bonus. You‚Äôre excited and tell everyone you know that you‚Äôre throwing a grand birthday dinner. You start planning early ‚Äî the menu, the decor, the guest list, everything! But then Diwali comes and goes‚Ä¶ and that big bonus your company gave you hopes of, never shows up. Suddenly, your party plans don‚Äôt quite fit the budget. You scale things down, cancel a few invites, and make do with a smaller celebration. The next day, there‚Äôs chaos. Friends whisper about how they were ‚Äúsupposed‚Äù to be invited to this grand bash that never really happened for them at least. Basically, not quite the birthday you imagined. Now let‚Äôs flip the story. This time, you keep your plans to yourself and wait until the bonus actually clinks in your account. When it does, you set a budget, finalise the guest list, send out invites, and host the perfect evening. The party goes smoothly, everyone has a blast, and months later, people are still talking about it. Now, I don‚Äôt need to ask which version you‚Äôd prefer. It‚Äôs undoubtedly the second one. And honestly, that‚Äôs exactly how, many companies eyeing a future stock market listing are thinking these days. For context, a few days ago, Infra.Market , a marketplace for construction materials, quietly filed its DRHP (Draft Red Herring Prospectus) with SEBI via the confidential, or what‚Äôs called, the ‚Äúpre-filing‚Äù route. Now, when a unicorn like Infra.Market, valued at a whopping $2.8 billion (‚Çπ24,850 crores), makes such a move, you‚Äôd expect the markets and media to be buzzing. But all that happened with Infra.Market were a few newspaper announcements, each carrying a disclaimer that ‚Äúthe pre-filing of the offer document shall not necessarily mean that the issuer will undertake the initial public offering‚Äù. And this isn‚Äôt an isolated case. Even Tata Capital‚Äôs IPO , whose subscription closes today, began with a confidential DRHP filing. In fact, ever since SEBI introduced this route in November 2022, 22 companies have filed their DRHPs quietly ‚Äî 18 of them in 2025 alone. So it naturally makes you wonder, ‚ÄúWhy are so many Indian companies choosing the hush-hush route before stepping into the spotlight?‚Äù Well, the opening example probably gave you a big clue. Companies prefer to keep their plans, and their numbers, under wraps until they‚Äôre absolutely sure about going public. Because if, after all that effort, they decide to hold off on the IPO, it can trigger a storm of speculation. The media starts talking, investors begin doubting, and the company‚Äôs reputation takes a hit. It‚Äôs something that could haunt it the next time it tries to raise funds. But that‚Äôs not the only reason. See, when a company files for an IPO the traditional way, its DRHP document becomes public for at least 21 days initially. Investors can comment, the media picks it up, and SEBI and the stock exchanges begin their review. Once they‚Äôre satisfied, the SEBI issues an observation letter, and the company gets 12 months to launch the IPO, after updating the DRHP with any changes, of course, and publishing what‚Äôs called the RHP (the final document before an IPO). Now here‚Äôs the catch. The entire DRHP, packed with business details, stays in the public domain through all of this. And that‚Äôs exactly what many firms want to avoid. Take Swiggy, for instance. It chose the confidential route for a reason. If it had gone the traditional way, rivals could‚Äôve easily accessed crucial data . Especially from Instamart, its quick commerce arm, like numbers, pricing strategies, customer insights, and even valuation details. That‚Äôs like handing competitors a cheat sheet before the game begins. And no company wants to leak that kind of information before it‚Äôs sure about going public. Because one of the trickiest parts of the DRHP process is handling revisions when SEBI or stock exchanges ask for clarifications. Sure, it‚Äôs a normal part of the procedure, but things can get messy when the media turns every back-and-forth into a headline. The WeWork India IPO , which just closed its subscription, is one of the best examples. While the IPO was fully subscribed, retail investors have raised concerns about alleged irregularities in the DRHP and questioned SEBI‚Äôs inaction. That‚Äôs not a good look, especially when the IPO is live, since it can impact subscription, valuations and how investors react once shares are allotted. Now contrast all of this with the confidential route and you see the big advantage that often gets overlooked. Founders here retain control over every stage. Unlike the traditional path, the confidential DRHP stays under wraps until SEBI issues its observation letter, with only limited visibility among qualified institutional buyers (QIBs). That‚Äôs a fancy term for sophisticated investors like mutual funds, banks, and insurance companies. And once SEBI offers its observations, the company has up to 18 months to launch the IPO or withdraw, as long as it files an updated DRHP within 16 months. That‚Äôs more time than the traditional route. And this gives companies the flexibility to pause if market conditions aren‚Äôt ideal ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs geopolitical tensions, trade wars, or a market bloodbath; without having to justify it publicly. Founders can gauge the market quietly and decide what timing‚Äôs the best. But there‚Äôs a small caveat here too, something analysts were worried about when the US opened up the confidential IPO route for companies intending to go public. See, the US introduced this route in 2012 to help smaller companies and startups with less than $1 billion in annual revenue go public without the fear of public scrutiny. By 2017, its market regulator, the SEC (Securities and Exchange Commission), extended the option to all companies looking to list. And since then, 86% of US companies have used the confidential route to begin their IPO process. But the thing is that besides the company‚Äôs executives, outside lawyers and bankers also get involved. That means the government or regulator‚Äôs employees may know inside details about pending offerings before investors do. And while it‚Äôs not easy to profit from this information, history shows that leaks and trading on insider knowledge aren‚Äôt unheard of. SEC employees themselves have been charged with trading stocks of companies under investigation, using unpublished, price-sensitive information to profit depending on whether the outcome of the investigation was positive or negative. So yeah, if such information slips out during an IPO‚Äôs pre-filing, it‚Äôs not all that different from regular public scrutiny. But honestly, that‚Äôs a minor hiccup in the bigger picture. What really matters is how this gives companies the confidence to go public on their own terms, helping them raise funds and strengthen India‚Äôs capital markets. Until next time‚Ä¶ Don‚Äôt forget to share this story on WhatsApp , LinkedIn , and X . A message to all the breadwinners You work hard; you provide and make sacrifices so your family can live comfortably. But imagine when you're not around. Would your family be okay financially? That‚Äôs the peace of mind term insurance brings. If you want to learn more, book a FREE consultation with a Ditto advisor today.

title: The LG Electronics India IPO
content_simple: 7 October 2025 ‚Ä¢ Capital Markets The LG Electronics India IPO In today‚Äôs Finshots, we break down the LG Electronics India IPO, which opens for subscription today and closes on October 9 th . But before we begin, if you love keeping up with the buzz in business and finance, make sure to subscribe and join the Finshots club, loved by over 5 lakh readers. Already a subscriber or reading this on the app? You‚Äôre all set. Let's get started with the story! The Story You‚Äôre probably thinking, ‚ÄúAnother IPO? Haven‚Äôt we had enough already?‚Äù Fair point. But this one‚Äôs not your regular market debut. It‚Äôs the biggest listing of the year after Tata Capital, and it comes from a company that‚Äôs probably sitting right in your living room. Because if you grew up in an Indian home in the 2000s, you already know LG. The maroon logo with a smiley on your fridge, or your TV, or the washing machine humming in the corner. It wasn‚Äôt just another brand but a part of many Indians‚Äô daily life. And now, that same company wants to sit not just in your living room but in your portfolio. LG Electronics, the Korean parent, is taking its Indian arm public. The offer size is ‚Çπ11,607 crores , and not a rupee of it will go to the company. It‚Äôs a pure offer-for-sale (OFS) where the parent is simply cashing out a slice of its stake after nearly three decades in India. Which begs the question ‚Äì why list something that doesn‚Äôt need the money? Well, because LG India has quietly grown into a heavyweight that deserves its own valuation tag. And India‚Äôs electronics market is a good example of why. Air conditioners have more than doubled in size, from ‚Çπ1.55 lakh crore in 2019 to ‚Çπ3.2 lakh crore in 2024. Home entertainment systems have expanded 2.5x in the same period, from ‚Çπ37,000 crore to ‚Çπ89,500 crore. But despite this boom, India still lags far behind other nations. Refrigerators reach only 35% of Indian homes, compared to 99% in China and 80% in the US. Washing machines? Just 22%. And microwaves? Barely 4%, versus 80% in the US and 20% in China. And come to think of it, that‚Äôs more of a potential runway for growth than a problem. And that‚Äôs the bet LG wants to own. The growth potential it is looking for is the untouched markets. The metros are saturated. The next frontier is Tier-2 and Tier-3 India, where rising incomes are meeting rising aspirations, and where appliances are still status symbols. So for LG India, that‚Äôs the new battleground. And with decades of trust and a massive presence, it could start with an upper hand. Its business today is split across two pillars: home applications and air solutions, and home entertainment. The first covers washing machines, refrigerators, and air-conditioners; the second includes TVs and audio systems. Together, they‚Äôve built India‚Äôs largest consumer electronics distribution network with over 35,000 retail (B2C) touchpoints spanning metros and small towns alike. And it doesn‚Äôt stop there. LG also runs the country‚Äôs biggest after-sales service network with 1,000+ service centres and over 13,000 service engineers. On the manufacturing side, its two plants ‚Äî in Pune and Noida ‚Äî can churn out 14.5 million products a year. That makes LG the largest in-house manufacturer of appliances in India. More importantly, the plants are designed for flexibility: a single assembly line can handle multiple products. And over half of LG‚Äôs raw materials (about 54%) now come from Indian suppliers, thanks to local vendor tie-ups. That means faster production, lower import bills, and stronger ‚ÄúMake in India‚Äù credentials. This scale and integration have made LG a market leader across four key categories ‚Äî washing machines, refrigerators, TVs, and inverter ACs. In FY25, its home appliances and air solutions division brought in ‚Çπ18,267 crores, or 75% of total revenue. Home entertainment added the remaining 25% with ‚Çπ5,672 crores. And that took the overall revenue to ‚Çπ24,366 crores, a steady rise from ‚Çπ21,352 crores a year earlier. Profits follow a similar pattern. LG India‚Äôs profit after tax (PAT), or the money left after paying all expenses and taxes, has risen steadily from ‚Çπ1,348 crores in FY23 to ‚Çπ1,511 crores in FY24, and ‚Çπ2,203 crores in FY25. Its return on equity (ROE), which measures how much profit a company generates for every rupee of shareholder money, improved from 27% in FY23 to 45% in FY25, while return on capital employed (ROCE) rose from 39% to 47% during the same period, showing just how efficiently LG uses its assets. So yeah, those are strong numbers for a 28-year old business. Which also answers our first question as to why the IPO isn‚Äôt about fundraising but signalling. That LG India is now big, profitable, and mature enough to stand on its own. The parent company is trying to unlock shareholder value, and prices LG‚Äôs India operations based on its individual performance. And it‚Äôs not an empty claim. Revenues have grown at 10.7% compounded annual growth rate (CAGR) between FY23 and FY25. The company also plans to deepen localisation further and may even set up a third plant in Andhra Pradesh. So even though the IPO proceeds won‚Äôt flow into India operations, listing visibility itself could strengthen partnerships and supplier confidence. All of which brings us to valuations of the IPO. The IPO price band is set at ‚Çπ1,080‚Äì‚Çπ1,140, implying a price to earnings (P/E) multiple of roughly 33‚Äì35x and a market cap of ‚Çπ77,000 crores. That‚Äôs lower than the industry average of 43x and puts LG India just below Havells (‚Çπ93,000 crore) in market valuations. Sure, there are other domestic peers like Voltas, Whirlpool, Blue Star, but they are smaller and less diversified. And since global rivals like Samsung, Sony, and Haier aren‚Äôt listed here, LG‚Äôs IPO stands out as India‚Äôs first true consumer-electronics giant on Dalal Street. But every legacy also has its cracks and you could see some for LG Electronics India too. Nearly 75% of LG India‚Äôs revenue in FY25 went into raw material costs, and 46% of those materials are imported from China, Korea, and Singapore. That leaves it vulnerable to currency swings and supply disruptions. It‚Äôs why the company has been actively working to localise more of its supply network and reduce import dependence. Competition in urban markets also remains brutal. So the next phase of growth depends on expanding deeper into India‚Äôs hinterland, where affordability and service reliability could decide who wins. Then there‚Äôs the dependency risk. LG India operates under a licensing agreement with the Korean parent, paying royalties of 2.3‚Äì2.4% (depending on the product) of sales for using its brand and technology. That‚Äôs fine when relations are steady. But if the parent tweaks terms or withdraws access, the Indian arm could lose the very identity that built its success. The parent company also owns another Indian subsidiary, Hi-M Solutek, which handles maintenance for LG‚Äôs air-conditioners. For now, it works exclusively with LG India ‚Äî but the contract isn‚Äôt binding. Any shift there could disrupt its massive service backbone. And there‚Äôs also a ‚Çπ4,717 crore tax dispute hanging over the company, which is nearly 73% of its current net worth. If the verdict doesn‚Äôt go its way, it could dent future profits. Still, despite those risks, this isn‚Äôt a company selling a dream. It‚Äôs selling a record. It‚Äôs not asking for money to build something new; it‚Äôs inviting investors to value what‚Äôs already built. And only time will tell whether that ‚ÄòLucky Goldstar‚Äô turns out to be lucky for investors too. Until then‚Ä¶ If this story gave you a quick breakdown of the LG Electronics India IPO, do us a favour and tell your friends, family, or even strangers about us on WhatsApp , LinkedIn , and X . title: Why UK manufacturing couldn‚Äôt afford a JLR on crutches
content_simple: 6 October 2025 ‚Ä¢ Business Why UK manufacturing couldn‚Äôt afford a JLR on crutches In today‚Äôs Finshots, we tell you how JLR‚Äôs cyberattack brought its factories and the UK‚Äôs manufacturing sector to their knees, and why cybersecurity matters just as much as assembly lines. But before we begin, if you love keeping up with the buzz in business and finance, make sure to subscribe and join the Finshots club, loved by over 5 lakh readers. Already a subscriber or reading this on the app? You‚Äôre all set. Let's get started with the story! The Story What happens when the code building your cars stalls before the engines do? A multi-million pound breakdown, closed factories, and a workforce with no choice but to stay indoors. This was the reality that Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) faced when a cyberattack struck in August. For almost a month, its factories lay defunct ‚Äî not just in the UK, but also in Slovakia, Brazil, and India. In fact, JLR hasn‚Äôt produced a single car since 31st August. But it wasn‚Äôt the only company under attack. The UK has seen a string of cyberattacks this year. Marks & Spencer‚Äôs (M&S) website and app were down in April due to a ransomware attack. Shoppers couldn‚Äôt make online purchases, and services were restored only recently. Another retail chain, the Co-op, also suffered a similar attack that cost it over ¬£80 million in profits. But while M&S and the Co-op eventually bounced back, the impact on JLR has been far greater. Every week its factories stayed shut, cost the company ¬£50 million. So why was JLR hit the hardest? For that you‚Äôll have to first understand what actually happened. It started two years ago, when JLR signed a five-year, ¬£800 million deal with TCS to rebuild its tech infrastructure. Since JLR has been owned by Tata since 2008, handing the job to Tata‚Äôs IT arm seemed natural. The plan was to modernise JLR‚Äôs digital systems, including a massive upgrade to SAP software ‚Äî the system that controls how car parts move around factories, how suppliers are linked, and even how luxury models are customised for top paying customers. In short, it was the backbone of JLR‚Äôs global production. But the problem was that JLR had connected ‚Äúeverything to everything‚Äù ‚Äî from smart factories to supplier systems. So when hackers (likely groups such as Scattered Spider, Lapsus$, or ShinyHunters) struck its core IT systems, production had to be halted immediately. And unlike older setups, JLR had to shut down almost everything, instead of just isolating the affected parts. The attack blocked access to critical systems that ran production lines, orders, payments, and even basic communication. Which means that JLR couldn‚Äôt build vehicles, place or pay for parts, or even process supplier invoices. For weeks, employees, suppliers, and logistics partners were left in limbo. So the bottom line was that the IT overhaul meant to make JLR more efficient ended up exposing its biggest weakness. But why does a cyberattack on just one automaker matter so much to the UK, you ask? Well, you see, JLR began life in 1922 making motorcycle sidecars in the UK. Fast forward a century, and it has grown into a multinational automaker designing, engineering, and building some of the world‚Äôs most recognisable luxury vehicles. Today, it‚Äôs not just another car company, but a pillar of the UK‚Äôs auto sector and a big cog in the broader economy. To put things in perspective, in 2024 alone, JLR contributed about ¬£17.9 billion to the UK economy. That‚Äôs roughly 0.6% of the country‚Äôs GDP. It directly employs around 33,000 people in the UK, with a supply chain that supports another 2 lakh jobs across hundreds of firms, many of them specialised local suppliers. In the West Midlands alone, where JLR‚Äôs main plants sit, it makes up nearly 5% of the regional economy. And it‚Äôs not just about the sheer volume of cars it produces ‚Äî nearly 1,000 vehicles a day at peak, but also exports, high-skilled jobs, and innovation in electric vehicles. So when JLR‚Äôs systems went dark, the ripple effects were brutal. Almost half its suppliers reported financial pain including unpaid invoices, delayed orders, and mounting costs. For many who depended solely on JLR, the shutdown meant layoffs, reduced hours, or even the threat of bankruptcy. Banks became reluctant to offer loans to affected suppliers without personal guarantees or collateral such as their homes, pushing many into liquidity crises. It got so bad that suppliers appealed for government help. And the UK government had to step in, touring factories and eventually guaranteeing JLR a ¬£1.5 billion loan to keep its supply chain afloat. What you can‚Äôt ignore is that this came at a time when UK manufacturing was already reeling from its worst slump since Covid. September was their worst month, with growth falling to a 4 month low , and energy and manufacturing costs rising. And just when things looked fragile, cyberattacks froze production. For Tata Motors too, the stakes are high. With 70% of its revenue tied to JLR, the parent company could be staring at a weak profit engine ahead. And absorbing the hit, especially without the cushion of cyber insurance, only makes the blow harder. Yup, you read that right. A Reuters story suggests that JLR didn‚Äôt have cybersecurity insurance, meaning they had to bear all the costs from the attack. They had not finalised a cyber insurance policy brokered by Lockton before the attack and therefore appear to have had no active cover for this incident. All of this makes you wonder ‚Äî how do you fix this, and more importantly, stop it from happening again? It‚Äôs going to take more than quick IT fixes. Companies like JLR need to treat cybersecurity the way they treat car safety. It‚Äôs not optional. That means building a proper cyber resilience framework that covers both the digital side and the factory floor. Regular risk checks, supplier audits, and learning from past incidents ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs JLR‚Äôs own hack or other high-profile breaches, should be the norm. But the basics matter most. Strong access controls with multi-factor authentication, regular password updates, and systems that can spot unusual activity early can make a huge difference. On the operational side, JLR needs a ‚Äúwhat if everything stops?‚Äù plan. Meaning, modern factories need a zero-trust approach where they assume that networks could already be compromised and focus on quick containment and response. Tested plans for downtime, supply chain delays, or production halts are crucial. And training employees for cyberattacks is just as important as fire drills. They could in fact, simulate attacks before they happen. Tabletop exercises and team drills that mimic real hackers expose weak spots, test defences, and ensure teams know exactly how to respond. Because the faster a company can detect, contain, and recover, the smaller the fallout. That way the next time a Range Rover rolls off the line, it won‚Äôt just be a triumph of engineering, it will be proof that in modern manufacturing, lines of code are as critical as bolts and engines. Until then‚Ä¶ If this story helped you quickly make sense of the JLR cyberattack and its ripple effects on the UK‚Äôs auto industry, share it with friends, family, or even strangers on WhatsApp , LinkedIn , and X . After all, it‚Äôs always nicer to have a smarter bunch of folks around you. Myth Alert: I'm Too Young to Buy Life Insurance! The other day, one of our founders was chatting with a friend who thought life insurance was something you buy in your 40s. He was shocked that it was still a widely held belief. Fact: Life Insurance acts as a safety net for your family. The younger you are, the cheaper it is. And the best part? Once you buy it, the premium remains unchanged no matter how old you get. title: üç≥Isabgol problems, Fat Bear Week, and more...
content_simple: 5 October 2025 ‚Ä¢ Sunny Side Up üç≥Isabgol problems, Fat Bear Week, and more... Hey folks! Every October in Alaska, the internet goes wild‚Ä¶ because of bears. Yes, bears. And it‚Äôs all for the crown of biggest, fluffiest bear of the year. Winter is coming, and these guys need to bulk up for months of hibernation. But humans turned it into a fun contest where anyone, anywhere, can vote for their favourite ‚Äúhibernator‚Äù. At Katmai National Park, the bear with the most votes wins Fat Bear Week . Over a million votes pour in from 100+ countries, all watching live on hidden bear cams. What started in 2014 as a way to teach people about bears has now become a global online tradition. Ranger Mike Fitz remembers spotting a fan post two photos of the same bear ‚Äî one in June and one in September. And the difference was jaw-dropping. Inspired, rangers hosted the first official Fat Bear Week in 2015. A decade later, it‚Äôs still going strong. But Katmai isn‚Äôt just about the competition. The park is home to over 2,200 bears , more than anywhere else in the world, and it‚Äôs packed with sockeye salmon ‚Äî the secret to these bears growing massive for the long winter ahead. Now you might wonder why it‚Äôs a voting contest and not based on size or weight. Well‚Ä¶ have you ever heard of anyone convincing a wild bear to step on a scale? Me neither. So yeah, until that happens, the voting is based on overall roundness and how well each bear has prepared for winter hibernation. This year‚Äôs winner is aptly named Chunk . Despite a broken jaw, he gorged on salmon, bulked up to around 500 kg , and beat 11 other competitors by over 30,000 votes. Beary interesting, eh? Here‚Äôs a soundtrack to put you in the mood üéµ Soma by Iyer‚Äôs Filter Coffee By the way, we‚Äôve run out of your song suggestions, so we went ahead and picked one ourselves. But we love listening to your picks and sharing them with our readers. So don‚Äôt leave us hanging. Send more songs our way! Now, let‚Äôs get cracking. What caught our eye this week üëÄ India‚Äôs Isabgol Problem About 22% of adult Indians suffer from constipation. Now, that‚Äôs not exactly the kind of stat you‚Äôd expect us to kick off a Sunny Side Up story with. But we had to, because the solution to India‚Äôs constipation problem is stuck in a problem of its own. Here‚Äôs what we mean. Just yesterday, isabgol processors threatened to stop buying isabgol seeds from farmers starting Monday (October 6th). The reason? A messy GST confusion that‚Äôs been choking their business. For context, India is the world‚Äôs largest producer of psyllium husk, or what we all know as isabgol. It‚Äôs basically a soluble fibre made from the seeds of plantago ovata, a herb that grows widely here. Farmers harvest the seeds, processors turn them into husk or powder, and voil√†, you get that age-old remedy for digestive troubles. Rajasthan grows nearly 70% of India‚Äôs isabgol crop, while 90% of the processing happens in Gujarat. But what‚Äôs even more interesting is that over 90% of this husk doesn‚Äôt even stay in India. It‚Äôs shipped off to the US, Europe, and Korea, where it‚Äôs in huge demand as a dietary fibre supplement and a medicinal laxative. And lately, it‚Äôs even caught the fancy of health-conscious youngsters abroad, who see it as a natural substitute (although unproven) for trendy weight loss drugs like Wegovy and Ozempic . But here‚Äôs where the troubles begin. Before GST replaced VAT in 2017, isabgol was exempt from tax. But under GST, only fresh isabgol seeds were exempt. Dried seeds and husk, on the other hand, attracted a 5% levy. The problem though is that the law doesn‚Äôt clearly define what ‚Äúfresh‚Äù actually means. And since processors typically buy through APMC markets (regulated marketplaces set up by state governments to ensure farmers get a fair price and aren‚Äôt exploited by middlemen) ‚Äî where it‚Äôs tough to certify whether seeds are fresh or dried, they play it safe and just pay GST on everything. Now, in theory, these GST payments get refunded later. But in practice, the refunds take ages. That means processors end up parking huge sums of money with tax authorities, when these funds could have otherwise kept their factories running smoothly. Add to this the pain of international tariffs that have already slowed export orders, and you can see why cash flow is giving them indigestion. And that‚Äôs why processors are threatening to shut down purchases, which is a huge problem. Because if they don‚Äôt buy seeds, the whole chain collapses. Farmers lose buyers, processors won‚Äôt run plants, and export orders will decline further. That‚Äôs a big deal for a country that dominates the global isabgol market. So yeah, until processors can ‚Äúease the constipation‚Äù of their blocked GST refunds, they don‚Äôt want to stock up on the very crop that has kept Indians‚Ä¶ ahem‚Ä¶ regular for decades. Now, it‚Äôs up to the government to prescribe the right medicine to fix this regulatory mess. Infographic üìä üì∫What if India abolished all taxes? Imagine waking up in a tax-free India ‚Äî no income tax, no GST, no nothing. Sounds like paradise, right? But what would really happen if all taxes vanished overnight? In this episode of Finshots TV, we break down the shocking reality of India‚Äôs taxation system: how much you truly pay, why the middle class bears the heaviest load, where your money actually goes, and the good and bad of what a tax-free India could look like. Click here to check it out . Readers Recommend üóíÔ∏è This week, our friend, Bhratesh Agrawal is back with another interesting book recommendation. He recommends reading House of Huawei by Eva Dou. It‚Äôs the untold story of the mysterious family dynasty at the heart of one of China‚Äôs most powerful companies, Huawei. Bhratesh says: The story of Ren Zhengfei and Huawei exposes the human face of China‚Äôs modern security state and gets to the heart of the central questions of the US-China trade war: How did these fast-growing Chinese companies emerge? Who really controls them? And what does China‚Äôs expanding surveillance web mean for the Chinese people, and for the rest of the world? Thanks for the rec, Bhratesh! That‚Äôs it from us this week. title: The Tata Capital IPO, India‚Äôs gold rush, and more‚Ä¶.
content_simple: 4 October 2025 ‚Ä¢ Weekly The Tata Capital IPO, India‚Äôs gold rush, and more‚Ä¶. In this week‚Äôs wrapup, we talk about private gold mining in India, how India became a French fry powerhouse, and why SMBC chose Yes Bank over Kotak Mahindra Bank to become its biggest shareholder. We also took a short Dussehra break, which is why you‚Äôre seeing fewer stories than usual. Also, in this week‚Äôs Markets edition, we break down the Tata Capital IPO that opens for subscription on October 6th and closes on October 8th. Click here to read the full story . With that out of the way, let‚Äôs look back at what we wrote this week. The gold rush begins at home India‚Äôs love for gold is a story that never ends. And to keep that love alive, we import about 1,000 tonnes of gold each year, but mine only about 1.5 tonnes from our own soil. Which honestly makes you wonder ‚Äî if demand is so huge, why don‚Äôt we mine more at home? There are legacy mines that go back to pre-Independence, like KGF and Hutti. When KGF closed in 2001, it mined about 800 tonnes of gold. It eventually shut down because mining became too expensive. Even with the few mines operating today, production still falls short of demand, partly due to policies that remained in place until the 2023 Mines and Minerals Act. But for the first time, private gold exploration and mining in India has become a reality ‚Äî the first proof of concept being the Jonnagiri gold project in Andhra Pradesh. Its first year might see an output of 750 kg, a modest number compared to imports, but enough to set an example. So, what does this mean for other critical minerals lying beneath our ground? Find out in our Monday story here . How India quietly became a French fry powerhouse Did you know that the potato is India‚Äôs most eaten vegetable? We produce nearly 60 million tonnes every year, making us the second-largest potato grower in the world. But until a few years ago, if you ordered French fries at McDonald‚Äôs, chances are those frozen spuds came from Europe. That story has changed lanes now with India exporting frozen potato products worth nearly ‚Çπ1,817 crores in FY25. That‚Äôs almost nine times what we did five years ago, with Gujarat at the heart of this transformation, producing around 80% of the country‚Äôs processed potatoes. So, how did a humble potato conquer the world‚Äôs French fry orders? Check out our Tuesday story here for the full ‚Äòbatata‚Äô revolution. Why did SMBC choose Yes Bank over Kotak Mahindra Bank SMBC (Sumitomo Mitsubishi Banking Corporation) held a slice in one of India‚Äôs leading banks: Kotak Mahindra. And on paper, that investment had almost everything: A CASA (Current Account and Savings Account) of 40%, an ROE (Return on Equity) of 12% and the stability that came from vesting in a large player. But one thing that it lacked was boardroom representation. Call it prestige without power, and that might be one of the reasons why SMBC walked away and picked Yes Bank. But why Yes Bank? After all, they almost collapsed back in 2020, had a tall stack of bad loans and sudden exits in its management. Get the full scoop here and find out if SMBC‚Äôs bet on Yes Bank can turn fruitful in the long run. Liked this wrapup? Don‚Äôt forget to share it on WhatsApp , LinkedIn , and X . title: The Tata Capital IPO explained
content_simple: 3 October 2025 ‚Ä¢ Markets The Tata Capital IPO explained In today‚Äôs Finshots, we take a closer look at 2025‚Äôs most awaited IPO ‚Äî the Tata Capital IPO, which opens for subscription on Monday, October 6th, and closes on October 8th. The Story This story barely needs an introduction. You probably already know Tata Capital as the financial services arm of the mighty Tata group. It kicked off in 2007 with the simple idea of offering financial services to retail customers, small businesses, and corporates. But as years passed by, the company widened its net. From consumer loans to commercial finance to wealth advisory, it slowly built itself into a brand that comfortably sat under the Tata umbrella. Fast forward to today and Tata Capital isn‚Äôt just another NBFC (Non-Banking Financial Company). It‚Äôs India‚Äôs third-largest diversified NBFC with assets under management or total loan book, standing tall at ‚Çπ2.33 lakh crores. And now, it‚Äôs gearing up to hit the market with a huge ‚Çπ15,512 crore IPO . The larger portion of this or ‚Çπ8,666 crores is an offer for sale. That‚Äôs basically Tata Sons (which owns 88.6% of Tata Capital) and another key shareholder, International Finance Corporation, cashing out a bit of their stake. Together, they own over 90% of the company. And post-IPO, the overall promoter holding will fall from 95.6% to about 85.5%. The remaining or ‚Çπ6,846 crores is a fresh issue. And that‚Äôs money Tata Capital will actually keep to strengthen its Tier-I capital. Think of this as the company‚Äôs financial cushion, made up largely of shareholders‚Äô money and retained earnings. The RBI insists that NBFCs maintain a strong buffer like this to ensure that they can absorb risks if loans go bad. And for Tata Capital, topping up this safety cushion doesn‚Äôt just mean ticking a regulatory box. It also creates more room to lend in the future. But does all of this automatically make its IPO a must-buy, you ask? Well, to figure that out, you‚Äôll need to dig into a few key numbers. Because it‚Äôs these metrics that will tell you whether 2025‚Äôs most hyped IPO actually lives up to the chatter. Let‚Äôs start with the topline or the company‚Äôs income. In FY25, Tata Capital clocked in about ‚Çπ28,300 crores in revenue from operations. That‚Äôs no small feat. In fact, it translates into a solid 44% compound annual growth rate (CAGR) over just the past two years, which seems impressive. But, when it comes to lending businesses like this, one number investors love to track is the Net Interest Margin (NIM). In simple terms, it‚Äôs the spread between what Tata Capital earns on the loans it gives out and what it has to pay on the money it borrows ‚Äî be it bonds, bank loans, or deposits. For Tata Capital, this margin currently sits at 5.2%. That‚Äôs not bad at all. But here‚Äôs the catch. It‚Äôs lower than the peer average of 7.6%. Big names like Bajaj Finance and Shriram Finance are miles ahead, with margins pushing 9.5‚Äì10%. Still, profits look healthy. Tata Capital pulled in ‚Çπ3,655 crores in FY25, growing at about 11% CAGR since FY23. But revenue and profits don‚Äôt paint the full picture. You also need to check how efficiently the company puts money to work. That‚Äôs where ratios like ROE (Return on Equity) and ROA (Return on Assets) step in. ROE tells you how much profit Tata Capital makes from every rupee of investor money. Here, it stands at 12.6%. Decent, but again, peers average closer to 16%. ROA, on the other hand, measures how effectively the company uses its loan book and investments to churn out profits. Tata Capital sits at 1.8%, while competitors average around 3.2%. Here‚Äôs the silver lining, though. If you look at asset quality, Tata Capital has been holding its ground quite well. Its Gross Stage 3 loans ‚Äî basically loans that haven‚Äôt been repaid for more than 90 days, have been steady between 1.5‚Äì2% over FY23 to FY25. That‚Äôs stronger than the industry average of about 2.6%, which shows that it does seem to have tighter control over the quality of its loan book. But even with these positives, there are a few risk factors you can‚Äôt ignore. Take its loan book, for example. On the surface, it looks well spread out across retail, SME, and corporate customers. And thanks to its recent merger with TMFL, Tata Motors‚Äô financing arm, it‚Äôs now a serious contender in vehicle finance too. TMFL alone brings in a big chunk of the commercial vehicle loans for the combined company. But the worrisome part is its unsecured loans or loans given without any collateral to fall back on, have consistently made up more than 20% of Tata Capital‚Äôs portfolio over the past three years. That‚Äôs not a small number. If too many borrowers default, it could eat into asset quality (which, to be fair, is currently better than peers) and force the company to set aside higher provisions. And that could hurt profitability down the line. Then there‚Äôs the legal overhang. Tata Capital has 283 criminal cases pending against it. Most of these revolve around loan disputes, repossession of vehicles, forgery allegations, or settlement issues. Typically, its borrowers or guarantors have taken the company or its employees to court and filed FIRs, claiming foul play. And while not all of these cases may be material in nature, together they add up to a contingent liability of ‚Çπ765 crores. To put that in context, this figure is way above the materiality threshold of ‚Çπ165 crores, which is 5% of the company‚Äôs average profit after tax over the past three years. And finally, there‚Äôs the valuation question. At the top end of the price band of ‚Çπ326 per share, Tata Capital would be valued at 33 times its earnings over the last twelve months and 4.2 times its book value. Compare that to its peers, which trade at a P/E (Price-to-Earnings ratio) of 27.2 and a P/B (Price-to-Book value) of 3.6, and it‚Äôs clear the stock looks a bit pricey. Add to that a market that‚Äôs already seeing a flood of massive IPOs, and this one could feel like a lot to digest. The Economic Times recently highlighted how mega IPOs over ‚Çπ10,000 crores have often disappointed. Take HDB Financial‚Äôs ‚Çπ12,500 crore IPO. It spiked 14% on listing day, but today it trades just 4% above its issue price. Or last year‚Äôs NTPC Green Energy ‚Çπ10,000 crore offering, which still lingers below its ‚Çπ108 issue price. And with LG Electronics‚Äô IPO coming up next week, investors may feel a little overwhelmed. So yeah, whether they'll still jump in on Tata Capital is something we‚Äôll have to wait and see. Even if they do, it may be more to do with the Tata tag rather than immediate gains, despite this being one of the year‚Äôs biggest IPOs. Until then‚Ä¶ If this story gave you a quick breakdown of the Tata Capital IPO, do us a favour and tell your friends, family, or even strangers about us on WhatsApp , LinkedIn , and X . title: Why did SMBC choose Yes Bank over Kotak Mahindra Bank?
content_simple: 3 October 2025 ‚Ä¢ Business Why did SMBC choose Yes Bank over Kotak Mahindra Bank? In today‚Äôs Finshots, we unpack why a Japanese giant gave up on Kotak Mahindra Bank to back a once-battered lender, and why, sometimes, control beats comfort. But a quick sidenote before we begin: 18% GST on Insurance Is Gone. What Now? Since 22nd September, the 18% GST on insurance premiums has been removed. Policies are now cheaper, but the real question is: which one should you get and how much cover do you actually need? That‚Äôs where our 2-day masterclass comes in. We‚Äôll break down health and life insurance in simple, jargon free steps so you can make the most of this change and avoid costly mistakes. üëâüèΩClick here to reserve your spot today! Now, onto today‚Äôs story. The Story Imagine you walk into a museum and see a masterpiece. No dust, no cracks, no sign of chaos. It‚Äôs flawless. But the moment you try to touch it, a siren goes off. Because perfect things aren‚Äôt meant to be altered. They‚Äôre meant to be admired from a distance. That‚Äôs exactly how SMBC (Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation) ‚Äì the Japanese banking giant ‚Äì felt holding a slice of Kotak Mahindra Bank. You see, on paper, Kotak was perfect. It had a return on equity of over 12%. A CASA ratio of around 40%. It was prized for discipline and loved by the markets, but also priced like it. SMBC held a 1.65% stake in the bank, earning the satisfaction that comes with owning a quality franchise. The catch? It was just a passive stake. No representation in the boardroom, no say in strategy, and no way to leverage its global strengths in trade finance or corporate banking beyond what Kotak already excels in. This is why SMBC walked away. In Kotak, it held prestige without power. In Yes Bank, it saw a second chance not just to invest, but to influence. But why Yes Bank? After all, back in 2020 , the company teetered on the edge of collapse. A ballooning pile of bad loans, sudden exits at the top, and a government-imposed moratorium on withdrawals turned the once high-flying bank into a cautionary tale. But the turnaround since then has been real. Under new leadership, gross and net non-performing assets (NPAs) have dropped to around 1.6%, deposits have bounced back to ‚Çπ2.85 lakh crore , and FY25 profits jumped over 64% . Sure, margins still trail top-tier peers, and legal baggage hasn‚Äôt vanished. Nobody‚Äôs calling it a finished product. But that‚Äôs exactly where the opportunity is buried. Yes Bank trades at just 1.4x book, the kind of valuation gap that excites growth-hungry investors. It‚Äôs the classic deep-value setup: embrace complexity, demand influence, and reap the upside if the rebuild holds. And this is where the difference lies. In Kotak, SMBC was a polite minority. At Yes Bank, it becomes the largest shareholder, holding just under 25% , with voting rights, two board seats, and equity affiliate status. Board representation enables SMBC to push governance forward, accelerate tech and risk upgrades, and, most importantly, integrate its Japan-based relationships directly into an Indian franchise that can serve those customers end-to-end. Think of the synergy map. SMBC sits on a deep roster of Japanese manufacturers, auto ancillaries, electronics suppliers, and trading houses expanding across India‚Äôs industrial corridors. Those clients require working capital lines, supply chain finance, foreign exchange risk coverage, cash management, and letters of credit. Then, there‚Äôs a second, subtler benefit. Turnarounds are powered by credibility arbitrage. A large, methodical shareholder with skin in the game shortens the time it takes for other stakeholders, depositors, bondholders, and rating agencies to gain confidence. You can‚Äôt just conjure that with press releases. You earn it with visible governance and the kind of oversight that only a board seat buys. ‚ÄúBut wasn‚Äôt Kotak the safer compounding machine?‚Äù Absolutely, and it still is. But that could also be a problem for a strategic investor looking for more than passive compounding. A premium-valued bank leaves little leftover return unless you bring a new engine of growth to justify an even higher multiple. With Yes Bank, the risk is higher, sure, but the levers are real: asset-mix upgrades, better pricing on corporate and SME books, cross-sell into a 1,200-branch network, and a digital stack that can be tightened with Japanese precision. Of course, this isn‚Äôt a fairy tale. Yes Bank‚Äôs margin profile remains squeezed compared to top-tier peers; the retail business takes time to rebuild, and corporate pricing is competitive. The legal overhang from legacy episodes still hasn‚Äôt disappeared. And a big investor can‚Äôt just micromanage collection zones or credit committees. The execution still sits with the management. But a partner like SMBC can tilt the odds with strong second-line risk teams, sharper treasury practices, and a pipeline of anchor clients that raise the average credit quality. After all, these are the compounding details turnarounds are made of. So, why not split the difference and own both? Well, that‚Äôs easier said than done. You see, SMBC wasn‚Äôt just allocating to ‚ÄúIndia financials.‚Äù It was buying a role. In Kotak, the role was that of a spectator. In Yes Bank, it‚Äôs a co-author. And the trade-off is a classic finance dilemma: influence over inertia vs controlled risk for premium comfort. If this thesis holds, here‚Äôs how it could play out: Deposit costs continue to ease as confidence builds. The mix tilts toward better-rated corporate and SME borrowers, aided by SMBC relationships, which lifts the risk-adjusted yield. Fee income climbs on trade finance and cash management. Credit costs remain contained if underwriting discipline is maintained. Combine these and book value compounds faster than the market anticipates. At that point, the multiple (1.4x Price-Book ratio today) has room to rerate without stretching credulity. You don‚Äôt need perfection but steady, boring progress. And if it doesn‚Äôt? Then the downside of a turnaround is the same as its lure: volatility. Legal surprises, a credit shock, or sloppy growth could crimp the story. The difference now is that a large shareholder has the tools and the obligation to course-correct inside the room, not from the sidelines. So, the bottom line is simple. SMBC didn‚Äôt really choose ‚ÄúYes Bank over Kotak.‚Äù It chose influence over inertia. It traded a premium, passive slice of a finished franchise for a meaningful stake in an unfinished one, with governance levers, two board seats, and the ability to integrate global clients into a domestic network. If the rebuild continues, the payoff can be outsized. If it stumbles, the costs will be visible and shared. And that‚Äôs the bet: not just parking capital in India, but planting a flag in a bank that can still change shape, and letting that change drive returns. Until then‚Ä¶ Sharing is caring. If you found this story useful, please do consider telling your friends about it. All you have to do is send it on WhatsApp , LinkedIn , or X and ask them to subscribe! :)

title: How India quietly became a French fry powerhouse
content_simple: 30 September 2025 ‚Ä¢ Business How India quietly became a French fry powerhouse In today‚Äôs Finshots we tell you how India went from importing French fries to becoming one of the world‚Äôs biggest exporters of processed potatoes. But here‚Äôs a quick sidenote before we begin: 18% GST on Insurance Is Gone. What Now? Since 22nd September, the 18% GST on insurance premiums has been removed. Policies are now cheaper, but the real question is: which one should you get and how much cover do you actually need? That‚Äôs where our 2-day masterclass comes in. We‚Äôll break down health and life insurance in simple, jargon free steps so you can make the most of this change and avoid costly mistakes. üëâüèΩ Click here to reserve your spot today! Also, please note that we‚Äôre taking a publishing break on October 1st (Dussehra) and October 2nd (Gandhi Jayanti). We‚Äôll be back on October 3rd. Until then, kick back, enjoy the holidays, and don‚Äôt miss us too much! üôÇ Now, onto today‚Äôs story. The Story The global French fries market is worth around $24 billion . But if you rewind by a couple of decades, India was nowhere in the picture or close to making or exporting these crispy snacks. Fast forward to today and the story looks very different. Potatoes have become India‚Äôs most eaten vegetable , and French fries have found their way into just about every menu. For context, India now produces a whopping 60 million tonnes of potatoes every year, second only to China. And we‚Äôre not just eating them, we‚Äôre exporting them too. In FY25 alone, India shipped frozen potato products worth ‚Çπ1,817 crores. That‚Äôs nearly nine times what we managed just five years ago, when exports were barely ‚Çπ217 crores. And quite surprising too, considering that India was once a net importer, bringing in 5,000‚Äì7,000 tonnes of potatoes a year in the mid-2000s. Which naturally makes you wonder ‚Äî how did this crispy love affair with French fries really begin? And how did India turn into such a big player in the game? To begin with, it makes sense that India was once an importer of potatoes and fries. After all, the potato isn‚Äôt even native to India. It first sprouted in the Andes of South America and only made its way here in the late 16th or early 17th century, thanks to European traders. The Portuguese are believed to have brought the ‚Äòbatata‚Äô to the Malabar coast, but it was the British who really pushed it across the country, especially in Bengal. For them, the potato was a handy famine-relief crop and a reliable staple that could thrive in India‚Äôs varied climates. And that‚Äôs how it became part of our home kitchens. But these were just your everyday table potatoes ‚Äî the kind you‚Äôd buy in a local market and cook at home. They didn‚Äôt fetch much money, mainly because India didn‚Äôt yet have the right varieties for processing or export. International buyers also demanded strict quality standards, and most small farmers simply couldn‚Äôt meet them. Add to that the lack of cold storage and transport facilities, and farmers didn‚Äôt have much incentive to grow potatoes commercially. In fact, things were often so bad that farmers in states like Bihar, Uttar Pradesh and West Bengal sometimes had to dump their produce, or even replant the same potatoes back into the soil, because selling them in the market wouldn‚Äôt cover their costs. That began to change in the early 2000s, thanks to McCain Foods ‚Äî the world‚Äôs largest producer of frozen potato products and the brand most of us know for its ready-to-cook snacks like French fries, burger patties, aloo tikki and more. McCain came to India in 1998, dabbling in agricultural R&D and trying to build a frozen food market. But it wouldn‚Äôt be fair to call them the pioneers because Lamb Weston, another American food giant, had been in India long before, importing frozen French fries for big star restaurants. McCain noticed how popular fries were getting and decided to join the party. And in 2007, they set up their first potato processing plant in Mehsana, Gujarat. And soon enough, it struck gold by becoming the exclusive supplier of frozen fries to McDonald‚Äôs, right after the US fast-food chain opened its first outlet here. That momentum didn‚Äôt go unnoticed. Indian potato-processing companies like HyFun Foods, Iscon Balaji Foods, Funwave Foods and ChillFill Foods jumped onto the bandwagon, and today, they rank among the country‚Äôs biggest potato processors alongside McCain. They saw how global giants such as Cavendish, Lamb Weston, McCain and JR Simplot, built empires out of fries, and they wanted a bite of that pie too. And the way they went about it was simple. They started striking contracts with farmers, agreeing on the price and quality of potatoes they‚Äôd supply. In return, farmers received benefits like assured prices and markets, access to credit, quality seeds, and guidance on better crop-growing practices. But these weren‚Äôt the everyday potatoes you find in your kitchen. These were special varieties, bred specifically for processed snacks like French fries. Like Santana and Frysona, the two big names in the global fries game. These potatoes, originally from Europe, are oblong, yellow-fleshed, high in starch, and low in sugar. That‚Äôs what gives fries their perfect crispiness and golden colour. Indian table varieties just can‚Äôt match them as they‚Äôre too watery and sugary, which makes fries brown too fast or cook unevenly. Interestingly, these foreign varieties thrive on Indian soil too, especially in Gujarat, where long days and mild, sunny winters are ideal for growing processing varieties of potatoes. On top of that, companies invested heavily in cold storage and logistics, making large-scale exports possible and sometimes even offering fries to overseas markets at prices lower than China . This contract farming setup didn‚Äôt just change the lives of farmers, but also transformed fortunes of Indian potato processing companies. To put things in perspective, farmers saw their incomes jump by an average of 75% since 2017 and companies started exporting potatoes from being just a domestic supplier earlier. Before this, countries in Southeast Asia, like the Philippines, Thailand, and Indonesia, as well as Middle Eastern markets relied mostly on the US and Europe, especially Belgium and the Netherlands, the world‚Äôs top exporters of frozen French fries, for their supply. But with the introduction of special processing potato varieties and contract farming, India became a reliable alternative, supplying French fries to markets that once seemed out of reach. Indian scientists played their part too. The Central Potato Research Institute (CPRI), under the Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR), developed varieties with low sugar and high dry matter ‚Äî perfect for fries that stay crispy and soak up less oil. Which is also why India‚Äôs shipping frozen potato products around the world. And that success sparked a wave of activity. More and more companies set up shop in Gujarat, diving into the manufacturing and sale of processed potatoes. In February this year, Indian frozen fries exports even crossed the 20,000-tonne mark for the first time. And Gujarat has been at the heart of this transformation, producing around 80% of the country‚Äôs processed potatoes. So yeah, that‚Äôs the fascinating story of how India went from being a net importer of potatoes to a major exporter. And it‚Äôll be exciting to see what happens next. Who knows, the day may not be far when we are neck to neck with large European fries exporters. Until then‚Ä¶ If this story gave you a quick deep dive into the world of French fries and where your favourite snack comes from, do us a favour and tell your friends, family, or even strangers about us on WhatsApp , LinkedIn , and X .

title: The gold rush begins at home
content_simple: 29 September 2025 ‚Ä¢ Economy The gold rush begins at home In today‚Äôs Finshots, we talk about how private gold mining might be the first step to reducing India‚Äôs reliance on imported gold. But here‚Äôs a quick sidenote before we begin: 18% GST on Insurance Is Gone. What Now? Since 22nd September, the 18% GST on insurance premiums has been removed. Policies are now cheaper, but the real question is: which one should you get and how much cover do you actually need? That‚Äôs where our 2-day masterclass comes in. We‚Äôll break down health and life insurance in simple, jargon free steps so you can make the most of this change and avoid costly mistakes. üëâüèΩClick here to reserve your spot today! Now, onto today‚Äôs story. The Story Indians and gold. It‚Äôs a love story that never ends. Whether it‚Äôs for weddings, savings, or just as an investment hedge, we can‚Äôt get enough of it. And to satisfy this appetite, India imports a thousand tonnes of this yellow metal. Yep, 1000 tonnes of gold every year! But when it comes to producing our own, the number is laughably small at just 1.5 tonnes. Which begs the question - When there‚Äôs such a steep demand, why haven‚Äôt we mined for gold at home? Well, we have mined in the past. And that‚Äôs also part of the reason why we haven‚Äôt anymore. Let us explain. The Kolar Gold Field (KGF), once the pride of Indian mining, churned out around 800 tonnes in the 120 years it was active before shutting down in 2001. The reason India stopped mining at KGF was because of a list of concerns. It was active for a long time, and that meant with more gold mined, the next extraction would be deeper. At one point, it was the 2nd deepest gold mine at 3,200 meters depth. And when you have to dig deeper, it costs more to extract gold. Think power costs, ventilation systems, water pumping all adding to the cost of getting the shiny metal out from underneath. And then there‚Äôs the environmental hazards that mining caused, especially contaminated water, land and infrastructure. So sure, it was the biggest gold mine of the country at the time, but after a point it was no longer viable. The closest we came to KGF was Hutti Gold Mine which gave us around 84 tonnes of gold between 1947 to 2020. So even if you put both these mines together, they didn‚Äôt move the needle. And even with the current active mines, we barely make enough to meet demand. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôve been a net importer of gold, buying from around 48 countries. Now you might be wondering, sure, the existing mines have run out of gold or they don‚Äôt make enough. So‚Ä¶ why not look for more gold reserves? Well, we have looked for them, and even know where they are. Most of the reserves sit in the southern belt of India, and Karnataka alone holds 88% of them. The remaining 12% sit in Andhra Pradesh. But for the longest time, the issue wasn‚Äôt where the gold reserves were, it‚Äôs how to get to them with the policies behind gold mining. Source: World Gold Council You see, until recently, there hadn‚Äôt been any true push for domestic gold mining. Most of the control here is with the government and companies never found it feasible to even bid for mining leases. Why‚Äôs that, you ask? Because for decades, mining these reserves was tied up in policy knots. All gold mining operations needed approval from the central government. But the actual licenses were handed out by the state government. There was no transparency nor was it based on competitive bidding. And even if a miner did manage to win the auction, there‚Äôs all the approvals that a private company needs: environmental clearances, wildlife approvals, forest clearances and land acquisitions. In short, starting a mine seemed like a paperwork nightmare before a single ounce of gold could be dug up. But all of this changed with the new 2023 Mines and Minerals (Development and Amendment) Bill . It introduced exploration licences (ELs) for private players, letting them scout for critical minerals ‚Äî gold included ‚Äî something the 1957 Act never allowed. Auctions were revamped too. Under a new reverse bidding system, exploration companies bid by quoting the smallest share they want from any future mining lease premium. So say if an exploration company discovers a viable gold deposit and the subsequent mining lease auction generates ‚Çπ100 crores in premium, the exploration company receives their quoted percentage share. In other words, exploration finally comes with a direct financial incentive. And we‚Äôre already seeing the first proof of concept: The Jonnagiri gold project. Located in the same belt as Karnataka‚Äôs gold mines, Jonnagiri is part of the East Dharwar craton in the Kurnool district of Andhra Pradesh. And it‚Äôs run by the Deccan Gold Mines Ltd (DGML), India‚Äôs only listed gold exploration/mining company. It‚Äôs also the first private gold mine, the first new discovery since Independence, and the first to be developed entirely under the 2023 exploration-license regime. That‚Äôs a lot of firsts from one project. And DGML followed through with environmental and land approvals that once kept private players out. In other words, it‚Äôs telling that the new policy can actually work. Once it‚Äôs fully operational, it could produce 750 kilograms of gold in its first year. Sure, it‚Äôs not as large as a thousand tonnes coming in from abroad. But it‚Äôs a statement that, this time, the gold rush isn‚Äôt at Kolar or Hutti, it‚Äôs in the hands of private miners. And when we‚Äôve been producing just 1.5 tonnes, that extra production can boost outputs by 60%! Fun fact:This isn't the first time gold mining came to Jonnagiri. Old debris and pounding marks indicate that the area has been worked by the ancients for recovering gold. These ancient workings led the Geological Survey of India to carry out a detailed investigation in 1991 . But here‚Äôs the million-dollar question: Will all of this really reduce our dependence on imported gold? Not immediately. Against annual demand of 800‚Äì1,000 tonnes, a few hundred kilos won‚Äôt change much. But it‚Äôs an important precedent. Because the same policy framework could unlock other critical minerals too. Apart from gold, a total of 107 blocks of minerals were given to state governments for auction, but only 19 were actually auctioned. So the central government took over the mining lease auctions for rhenium, tungsten, cobalt and many other minerals. Faster auctions mean production can start sooner and we can finally see real use of our minerals. And as more private explorers enter the field, new deposits could be discovered and India‚Äôs dependence on costly imports could gradually reduce. Until then‚Ä¶ Sharing is caring. title: Lying mirrors, pigeons & AI, and more‚Ä¶
content_simple: 28 September 2025 ‚Ä¢ Sunny Side Up Lying mirrors, pigeons & AI, and more‚Ä¶ Hey folks! Imagine you‚Äôre in a Uniqlo trial room. The mirror tells you the shirt fits like a dream. You buy it, but at home? You have the same shirt, same you‚Ä¶ but you look less dashing. Like the magic‚Äôs gone. That‚Äôs exactly what shoppers in China accused Uniqlo of recently. Social media posts under #UniqloMirror claimed that the brand‚Äôs trial room mirrors slimmed waists, softened complexions, even changed how colors looked. Uniqlo denied it, insisting their mirrors are plain vanilla glass. We obviously don‚Äôt know who‚Äôs right here. But here‚Äôs the thing. Stores and brands don‚Äôt need fancy tech to shape how you see yourself. Lighting, angles, muted backdrops‚Ä¶ every detail is often engineered to make you like what you see. And once you like what you see, you buy. That‚Äôs impulse shopping in action. The emotional brain shouts ‚Äúyes‚Äù long before your rational brain can whisper ‚Äúmaybe later‚Äù. And brands have always thrived on these nudges. Think of how most lean on urgency: ‚ÄúOnly last few left!‚Äù Or how a colour suddenly becomes the colour of the year (2025‚Äôs is Mocha Mousse , in case you‚Äôre wondering). Even brand names are psychology hacks. Like how Lululemon‚Äôs founder once admitted he chose the company‚Äôs name because it was harder for Japanese consumers to pronounce the letter ‚ÄòL‚Äô, making it feel exotic. These tricks prey on the same human quirk. That we‚Äôre not nearly as rational as we think after all. And impulse purchases aren‚Äôt a failure of willpower. They‚Äôre more about environments built to exploit those weaknesses. So maybe the real ‚Äúlying mirror‚Äù isn‚Äôt in Uniqlo‚Äôs showroom at all. Maybe it‚Äôs in our heads, reflecting the version of ourselves that shops on instinct. And in an era where every store and every screen is nudging us to do so, a good hack is catching yourself in the act (maybe in front of a mirror itself! :)) It‚Äôs super hard to skip these, we know. But it‚Äôs also a nice way forward, yeah? To sometimes outsmart your own psychology before it empties your wallet. Here‚Äôs a soundtrack to put you in the mood üéµ This world is a strange place by The Kush Upadhyay Group What caught our eye this week üëÄ AI is all thanks to Pigeons?! If you think pigeons are just winged freeloaders squatting on your balcony, think again. Because these birds might have given us the blueprint for artificial intelligence. Yeah, no kidding! Back in the 1950s, a psychologist named B.F. Skinner put pigeons in boxes and trained them with food pellets. If they pecked the right button, they got a reward. But peck the wrong one and they go hungry. And through this simple system of trial and error, pigeons soon learned to perform surprisingly complex tasks. Sidebar: At one point, Skinner even pitched a plan to the US military to use pigeons to guide missiles. And while that sounds nuts, the birds were surprisingly accurate. By the 1990s, scientists noticed something stranger. Pigeons could recognize patterns humans often failed at. Show them a set of photos, and they‚Äôd sort trees, or tell a Monet from a Picasso . Because they were brilliant at one thing: relentless learning. Keep pecking, keep failing, keep adjusting. Over and over. Fast forward to today. In a new study , researchers flashed pigeons abstract visuals like lines, rings, odd shapes. At first, they guessed, hitting about half accuracy. But after enough tries, they improved. On easier tasks, they reached 95%. Even on near-impossible ones, they still got better. Now, here‚Äôs where the AI connection comes in. The study shows how pigeons‚Äô learning style is nearly identical to how machine learning works. Both pigeons and AI rely on associative learning (linking ‚Äúthis stimulus means that response‚Äù) and error correction (‚Äúwrong choice? adjust and try again‚Äù). There‚Äôs no big rulebook, no human-like reasoning. Just repetition until the system gets it right. And this is exactly where humans actually perform badly. We get stuck trying to invent neat rules like ‚Äúall verticals go left, horizontals go right.‚Äù And when no rule fits, we get frustrated and quit after the overthinking lag. Pigeons, however, don‚Äôt bother with rules. They just brute-force their way through, mistake after mistake, until they crack it. The researchers even built a simple AI model using the same method ‚Äî associative learning plus error correction. And its learning curve looked just like the pigeons‚Äô. In other words, what we celebrate as cutting-edge intelligence is, as its core, bird brain logic. And if you think that‚Äôs the end of their tech story, just remember Nikola Tesla , the man who gave us alternating current and wireless dreams, adored pigeons. He spent hours feeding them, claimed they inspired his thinking, and once said that when his favorite white pigeon died, something went out of his life. So maybe it‚Äôs time we give pigeons more credit. The next time one struts past you at a tea stall, don‚Äôt dismiss it as a flying rat. You might just be looking at the original neural network, cooing away in plain sight :) Infographic üìä Readers Recommend üóíÔ∏è This week, our reader Shahzad, recommends reading Investment Biker by Jim Rogers. He says, It‚Äôs a wonderful travelogue by the famous commodities trader Jim Rogers. I first read it during my MBA days in 2008, and I was really hooked on the insights I got from his real-world adventures. It‚Äôs a very good read for anyone who loves to travel, understand different cultures, and explore the economies of those countries. Thanks for the rec, Shahzad! That‚Äôs it from us this week. We‚Äôll see you next Sunday! Until then, send us your book, music, business movies, documentaries or podcast recommendations. We‚Äôll feature them in the newsletter! Also, don‚Äôt forget to tell us what you thought of today's edition. Just hit reply to this email (or if you‚Äôre reading this on the web, drop us a message at morning@finshots.in ). üññüèΩ Don‚Äôt forget to share this edition on WhatsApp , LinkedIn and X .

title: TCC‚Äôs bet on Pepperfry, Trump dislikes quarterly results, Nvidia‚Äôs Intel gamble & more‚Ä¶
content_simple: 27 September 2025 ‚Ä¢ Weekly TCC‚Äôs bet on Pepperfry, Trump dislikes quarterly results, Nvidia‚Äôs Intel gamble & more‚Ä¶ In this week‚Äôs wrapup, we break down the Anand Rathi Share and Stock Brokers IPO, why Donald Trump just slapped a $100,000 toll on H-1B visas, Nvidia‚Äôs surprising $5 billion bet on Intel, Trump‚Äôs attack on quarterly results, and whether the desert of Kutch could decide the future of India‚Äôs green energy. And in this week‚Äôs Markets edition, we dive into realty firm TCC Concept‚Äôs potential acquisition of Pepperfry and explore why a loss-making omnichannel furniture retailer seems to be a bet worth making. Click here to read the full story . With that out of the way, let‚Äôs recap what we wrote this week. The Anand Rathi Share and Stock Brokers IPO explained Brokerage firms often live and die by market moods. And Anand Rathi Share and Stock Brokers (ARSSBL), which hit the public markets this week, with a ‚Çπ745 crore IPO, wants investors to bet on its full-service model from research, advisory, portfolio management, and more. Sure, the timing seems right. Household savings are steadily shifting from deposits to markets, margin trading is growing at breakneck pace, and ARSSBL has clocked a 35% compounded annual growth rate in revenues over the past two years. But dig deeper and you see that discount brokers control nearly 80% of the industry, ARSSBL‚Äôs profitability trails peers, and the shadow of the NSEL scam still looms. And to know more about these things, you can check out our Monday‚Äôs story . The $100,000 H-1B visa shock Donald Trump slapped a $100,000 fee on new H-1B visas, up from about $1,000. Considering 70% of these visas go to Indians, the shockwaves were instant. The White House insists this is a one-time fee, but the fine print tells a bigger story ‚Äî agencies have been told to rejig how visas are prioritised and how wages are benchmarked. Which means higher-paid jobs get preference, while entry-level roles could face the heat. And for Indian IT firms, the calculus changes: why pay $100,000 per engineer in the US when you can expand delivery centres out of the US? But for India, that could even be a blessing in disguise like more talent staying back, deeper domestic markets, and global capability centres booming. The question then is does this policy protect American jobs, or push them offshore faster? That‚Äôs what we unpack in our Tuesday‚Äôs newsletter . The Intel‚ÄìNvidia saga For years, Intel was the king of chips. But then came the delays, yield disasters, and a slow erosion of its crown. AMD surged ahead in CPUs, TSMC became the world‚Äôs foundry of choice, and Intel turned into a laggard. So why on earth is Nvidia, the hottest AI-chipmaker today, spending $5 billion to take a stake in this wounded rival? The answer is insurance. You see, Nvidia‚Äôs entire empire runs on chips made in Taiwan by TSMC, and that‚Äôs a geopolitical gamble. By working with Intel, Nvidia gets to diversify supply chains, score political points in the US, and access Intel‚Äôs still formidable ecosystem. Intel, meanwhile, gets relevance and the whiff of a turnaround story. But is this partnership a true Plan B, or just another weak link in an already fragile supply chain? You can read our Wednesday‚Äôs story here for all the answers. President Trump dislikes quarterly results now? Quarterly earnings are Wall Street‚Äôs heartbeat. Every three months, companies release their numbers, analysts read them closely, and share prices swing. But Trump isn‚Äôt a fan of this. He says the ritual eats up time and money, and worse, it forces managers to chase short-term results instead of long-term growth. His solution? Scrap quarterly reports altogether and go back to semi-annual updates. Now that sounds simple, but the evidence suggests otherwise. The UK tried it and found that companies didn‚Äôt suddenly invest more for the long term. Instead, many kept reporting quarterly anyway just to stay visible. And fewer disclosures could mean more room for insiders to trade on private knowledge, eroding trust in markets. So we study this issue more, and try to make sense of it all in our Thursday newsletter . 10% of Kutch for green energy and data centres = development? Kutch is India‚Äôs salt desert, but now it‚Äôs turning into the country‚Äôs green energy capital. Reliance is pouring ‚Çπ75,000 crores into hydrogen and batteries. Adani is building a 30-GW sprawl of solar and wind farms. And between them, they‚Äôve cornered nearly a million acres‚Ä¶ or about 10% of the district‚Äôs land. On paper, it looks like a clean-energy jackpot. But the story isn‚Äôt as shiny. Because Reliance‚Äôs hydrogen dream needs pipelines that don‚Äôt exist and Adani still carries coal baggage that could spook investors. And the desert‚Äôs fragile ecology is at risk ‚Äî endangered bustards colliding with power lines and thousands of litres of water being guzzled for solar panels. And much of this power could go to the west's data centres. So on paper, Google and Meta look greener, but on the ground, Kutch pays the price. So what‚Äôs the way out? That‚Äôs something we talk about in our Friday‚Äôs story to answer if this is real development, or just a mirage? Liked this wrapup? Don‚Äôt forget to share it on WhatsApp , LinkedIn , and X .
